Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Life on the Edge: The Effects of Climate, Competition and History on Range Limits
Award.AbstractNarration:
Why are coconut trees never found north of Florida while Christmas trees (i.e. balsam firs) never grow south of Pennsylvania? These species differ in their tolerance of climatic stressors like frost and drought, thereby limiting their distributions to an area termed the species "range". Despite a century of study, scientists are only beginning to understand which factors, including climate, influence the boundaries of these ranges. To address these fundamental gaps in our understanding, the investigator will utilize observational data, experiments and mathematical models to study current and future ranges of five tree species on Mt. Rainier, Washington. The project will assess how competition with other tree species interacts with climate to limit ranges for each tree species; determine whether the distributions of target tree species reflect past as opposed to current climates; and determine how quickly ranges of target tree species can shift in response to the rapid rates of climate change predicted for the Pacific Northwest.

The broader impacts of the proposed research are threefold. The study species are economically valuable timber species, and dominate western Washington forests that provide ecosystem services such as water supply, habitat for endangered species and storage of carbon. Thus, the information gained from this research will be valuable to conservation biologists, land managers and policy makers planning for climate change. The investigator will develop a climate change curriculum for an introductory biology class at University of Washington (reaching >2000 undergraduates per year) and a high school course. A citizen science program at Mt. Rainier National Park will increase the general public's awareness of how climate change impacts the natural world.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Why are coconut trees never found north of Florida while Christmas trees (e.g. balsam firs) rarely grow south of Pennsylvania? Ecologists believe that coconut trees and balsam firs differ in their ability to tolerate climatic stressors like frost and drought, thereby limiting their distributions to an area termed the species ‘range’. However, scientists do not fully understand which factors, including climate, influence the boundaries of these ranges – despite a century of study on these topics. This project was designed to address these fundamental gaps in our understanding. Specifically, the Principal Investigator (PI) and her students have utilized observational data, experiments and mathematical models to study current and future ranges of trees at Mt. Rainier National Park (Washington, USA). Additionally, the PI and her students increased the awareness of scientific methods and scientific research for students and the general public. In particular, the PI developed educational materials for biology classes at University of Washington (reaching >2000 undergraduates per year) and initiated a citizen science program at Mt. Rainier National Park called MeadoWatch (involving 100+ volunteers in scientific research at Mt. Rainier annually).

Intellectual Merit Outcomes: One the most commonly expected impacts of climate change are the poleward and uphill movement of species (range shifts). The PI has made several important discoveries that allow us to understand the complexities of that general response. First, she and her students have demonstrated that species will differ in the direction and magnitude of range shifts, because species differ in the climatic factors that constrain their performance at range boundaries (e.g. snow duration or soil moisture). Second, she has demonstrated that interactions with other species (e.g. competitive interactions) often play an important role in driving range boundaries, and thus, that such interactions can moderate or exacerbate range shifts (or at the very least, complicate them). Finally, the PI has also shown that long-lived and slow growing species, such as the long-lived tree species of the Pacific Northwest, can be slow to respond to climate change, implying that a lack of biological response to climate change may represent a delayed vulnerability, rather than a resilience to climate change.

Broader Impact Outcomes: The PI's many outreach efforts has allowed undergraduate students and the general public to gain insight in the process of science and the potential magnitude of climate change impacts through exposure and involvement in the local impacts of climate change. In the process, the PI and her research team has demonstrated that citizen science programs like MeadoWatch show great potential in engaging citizens in science while generating large amounts of data relevant to studies on the biological impacts of climate change. In the process of gaining scientific insights, the PI has trained two postdoctoral research fellows, five graduate students, and over forty undergraduate students – almost all of which have used the skills they learned to gain conservation / ecology related jobs in academia, state, and local organizations.

Communication of Results: Insights gained from the funded research have been communicated to other scientists and the general public in several ways. Nearly 20 peer reviewed scientific manuscripts have directly resulted or been influenced by grant activities, with more publications on the way. The PI and other personnel associated with the grant (e.g. graduate students) have presented posters or oral talks at national and international meetings annually. The PI has also given many talks for the general public at local organizations (e.g. Washington Native Plant Society). Additionally, the PI and her students participate in the training of seasonal interpretative staff at Mt. Rainier National Park annually (these 30+ seasonal staff each interact with 100s of visitors). Finally, a citizen science program called MeadoWatch (initiated with support from this grant) has involved over 200 volunteers in scientific data collection since its inception in 2013, additionally generating >100,000 data points.
